They both have their advantages and such. Both are supported about the same but I think the IRC support for Gnome is better than KUbuntu. But both of them are about as well built and stable. No you don't need to dual boot. It's integrated into Ubuntu.
I mean't if I wanted to have a dual boot of windows on my computer.
You'll just choose your login manager (probably GDM would be better (Gnome based)) and you can choose Gnome or KDE. There are also other WMs available such as Enlightenment, etc.
